/COMMIT_MSG.message: s/got/for/

This feels similarly to what we had with IPMI, and I wonder if the solution should be the same: to enqueue all commands and execute them with a delay.

Otherwise you're assuming a specific order in which power off and on are called.

author.name: Julia Kreger
author.status: On the moon! With a jetpack!

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
The code for IPMI doesn't always work if a new task triggers it. And given that power on/off are the only actions, I feel like maybe we should just go with the simplest path Chris has proposed.

Perhaps a bigger question, which will push me in the direction of what Dmitry suggests. Is it just the command for the port which is failing, or is it the commands in general for an entire pdu power strip?

common/deploy-steps-playbooks-common.yam.message: IIUC we should replace this as well but replacing this by Group results in pep8 failure...
No if you look this has no actual execution logic and is purely a data check. localhost is fine
This is rendered on the localhost (host executing) not necessarily the undercloud.

common/deploy-steps-tasks-step-0.j2.yaml.message: Once again this is a logging task and localhost is correct

common/deploy-steps.j2.message: This is a logging task and should not be run with anything but localhost

yes, like if running on a laptop, while having an undercloud in inventory as another host, it should still work locally, correct?..
or do you mean standalone case, where there is no undercloud at all?

The only reason to delegate to undercloud is if you need to execute code on the undercloud (e.g. doing overcloud openstack actions).  Everything else that's localhost is usually because the expectation is that we want to run it on the thing running ansible.  Which may or may not be an undercloud.  I believe we still build out an undercloud role in the standalone so these still work but it's effectively localhost. I'd have to double check.

FYI: So far the Undercloud group is defined in inventory even in a standalone deployment.

 https://d4698fe03376793369e5-3f28c2c0c6b192e8ac5a4ae954bec2d0.ssl.cf1.rackcdn.com/810389/2/check/tripleo-ci-centos-8-scenario002-standalone/ea3a433/logs/undercloud/home/zuul/tripleo-deploy/standalone-ansible-djabsxb5/inventory/tripleo

my understanding those delegates should run on computes, not undercloud?
mhm, but there is no more nova on undercloud since...W?
It runs on the undercloud because this is a scale down task.  I wonder if the scale down tasks still get the full inventory since we ditched mistral

This should be executed in undercloud because this required access to API endpoint and clouds.yaml (see L1650 which uses OS_CLOUD). This commit doesn't effectively change behavior but just change how it is defined so if this should be fixed then that's a separate topic IMO.

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/cert_mon/cer.message: should reference already defined constant at sysinv/common/   constants.OS_INTERFACE_INTERNAL
Since this just went through I'll keep both of the above comments in mind and perhaps sneak them into the next commit.

John: I think I'd prefer to leave this as a hard-coded string actually. It's not tied to the interface name here - it's just delimiting between two keystone token instances: one used for internal API calls and the other for subcloud API calls. I'm not even sure that 'internal' is a good name here - maybe 'local' is better, but for now I'd prefer to stick with it the way it is.
I probably will name the two cache as "central" and "subcloud", since one is used for access system controller dcmanager, the other is used for accessing subclouds.
ok, thanks for clarifying, I see the distinction now, so its ok.

It might have fit as a constant within TokenCache  ie: TokenCache.INTERNAL
but that would only offer value once token cache starts to be used by the other components in sysinv.

should this be a debug log?

This parameter is actually required here because it is invoked with the compact argument via the patched get_dc_token side_effect setup by the mock.patch() call on line 313 below. We're patching the call to utils.get_dc_token(region_name, compact) with this get_cache_test_token function.

unless the full exception traceback is needed, LOG.warn() sufficient ?

You can manually test the chart changes using the --debug --dryrun option on an install and feed it an overrides file.

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
Hopefully the transition date will match these periods.
My main concern is that series are not equal in term of number of weeks, and extended maintenance is fixed to 18 months after the initial release, so I think that with time it may slip.

In other words, series duration and stable periods aren't really  synced.

Personally I was more thinking to schedule less strict in term of week, based on the schedule displayed at https://releases.openstack.org/ and transposed to the current series agenda.

That's my opinion and it shouldn't take as a change request but more as an open discussion about it.

That is completely true that EM is not synced with the weeks rather it is planned to 18 months after the initial release. On the other hand we usually moved the transition date to fall into a calm period in the last couple of occasions.

We don't backport new properties for resource plugins unless we agree for an exception here.

zuul/ansible/callback/zuul_stream.py.message:
This might be a dumb question, especially since we've been using this for a while now, but are we certain these are the right keys?

If I run "ansible localhost -m setup", I can find a 'ansible_hostname' variable in the output, but not a "ansible_host". And I can find *no* reference to 'ansible_inventory_host' anywhere in Ansible source code, although their docs do reference a "inventory_host" hostvar (http://docs.ansible.com/ansible/latest/playbooks_variables.html#magic-variables-and-how-to-access-information-about-other-hosts).
I guess it's actually "inventory_hostname" that their docs reference, but I can't find that in any sample output that I've tried, either.

zuul/ansible/logconfig.py.message: This isn't actually used anywhere that I can find in this or following reviews.

zuul/executor/stream.py.message: How does a unix domain socket help?  (Also, holy cow, openssh can forward unix domain sockets!)

Right?

Forwarding a unix domain socket would at least get us a bit of obscurity, since I'd imagine we'd forward it into the remote tmp dir. That way, rather than always logging to port 4090 on the remote host (which would be pretty wide-open to anybody sending packets to) the filename and directory would be different per run. Still probably want to consume json instead though.

That said - unix domain socket would also get us less conflict with the remote machine - we would not have to open *any* ports, so we'd be conflicting with test env less.

As per https://libvirt.org/manpages/virtproxyd.html  there is no --listen parameter, we have to set listen_tcp and listen_tls in virtproxyd_config.

Good point. Originally, this script is generic for adding a launchpad comment for any reason. I'm thinking maybe it would be best to leave this optional and only set the status if it has been specified -- doing this would allow it to still be used as a generic script for adding a launchpad comment. I will try this and see what you think on the next PS.

Maybe even the 'series' can be added if there is no such target, though I haven't used launchpad module that much and don't know whether it would work. But as a first step let's just stick to this solution. :)

This is a nice idea. I will look into how to add that at patch proposal time (I think it would be better than waiting till release time). A common workflow for me is I go and add series on the bug by hand when someone proposes a backport.

> I note that in [1] it should really be using endswith('/' + series) to further ensure it doesn't choose coincidental substrings. Although, maybe we can't assume series will have '/' in it necessarily. That's probably why it doesn't use '/'.

Most of our launchpad projects use series names without '/' like 'xena', 'wallaby' and so on. At least nova, neutron and cinder launchpad projects do so.

AFAIK Launchpad serieses can be created only by launchpad project maintainers. I think we need to create serieses in advance.

Hm, I notice that existing code like this uses endswith() instead [1]. I think that makes sense, so it has less of a chance of choosing coincidental bug_target_name that have a substring (series) in the middle. Example: stable/some vs stable/something for series=some.

I note that in [1] it should really be using endswith('/' + series) to further ensure it doesn't choose coincidental substrings. Although, maybe we can't assume series will have '/' in it necessarily. That's probably why it doesn't use '/'.

[1] https://opendev.org/opendev/jeepyb/src/commit/faca72ce59bfce0758f5f3f7eed3e71f98a35a18/jeepyb/cmd/update_bug.py#L195

> @melwitt - we could make sure that it matches a regexp with '\bSERIES$' (just replace SERIES with the real series). This way it works with both slashed (never seen but could happen) and unslashed variant.

Nice idea, I shall use it. :)

@melwitt - we could make sure that it matches a regexp with '\bSERIES$' (just replace SERIES with the real series). This way it works with both slashed (never seen but could happen) and unslashed variant.

@Akihiro - That true, but I think here melwitt and Elod meant that you might have a bug that is not tracked in a specific (existing) series but you have actually merged a fix to it. I agree with melwitt that it should rather be handled at patch proposal time if at all. ;-)

The first character is specifieid by pos 1 and the second character is specified by pos 2. 0 also works, but it is easier to understand if we use "1' instead as subst($0,2) means to extract substring starting with 2nd character.

My Windowz has

  GNU bash, version 5.1.4(1)-release

but only because it has Debian Bullseye in WSL2. 😜
++ to use Bash 4.0 if Elod approves.

Aside, lol my macbook has:
 $ bash --version
 GNU bash, version 3.2.57(1)-release (x86_64-apple-darwin18)
I did see simpler things with Bash 4.0 when I was googling but I wasn't sure if we can assume Bash 4.0. If so, your way is much much better.
I figured this might actually make little sense when we accept slashed variants but meh!

sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/fpga_agent/m.message: Maybe we should consider making this loop for 10 minutes or so rather than infinitely.  Any N3000 devices should be reset on system startup.  If there are no N3000 devices on the system, it's a bit of a waste.  What do you think?
Right.  There were changes made to puppet that will reset any detected N3000 devices, early on, even if they are not configured by the user.

It's my understanding that using "ctr" to do this is only valid before Kubernetes is up and running.  According to https://kubernetes.io/docs/tasks/debug-application-cluster/crictl/ :

"Using crictl to create a container is useful for debugging container runtimes. On a running Kubernetes cluster, the sandbox will eventually be stopped and deleted by the Kubelet."

Have you proven that this will not affect us in our environment?

I would have expected that after Kubernetes is up and running we would want to run the fpgasupdate command in a kubernetes pod so that it doesn't kill the container partway through the image update (which could last 40 minutes or more).

I talked with an upstream kubelet developer who said that kubelet shouldn't affect containers started with "ctr", so the only thing we need to verify is whether ctr containers are setting the CPU affinity correctly or if we need to do something explicitly about affinity.
The cpu affinity of the ctr container is set to all the CPUs on the host. However, I noticed that all the other kube containers are also set to use all CPUs.
This is a logic change.  Should we have been waiting for the reset previously rather than just the docker login?
We probably could have been waiting for the reset previously.
I think "platform" might make more sense here.  Could potentially use it for other things as well in the future.
As per our chat, the container isn't actually running after a reboot.  It'd be more accurate to say that the container exists but isn't actually running.

Do we need to add something to https://opendev.org/starlingx/monitoring/src/branch/master/kube-cpusets/kube-cpusets/kube_cpusets/kube_cpusets.py#L142 ?  I think the answer is no because it should be detected here: https://opendev.org/starlingx/monitoring/src/branch/master/kube-cpusets/kube-cpusets/kube_cpusets/kube_cpusets.py#L317 but please have a look at this
'crictl ps' does not list the containers created by ctr.

tripleo_ansible/roles/tripleo_stream_ena.message:
I would suggest changing this to enable passing a list of dicts, something like:

tripleo_stream_enable:
  - module: foo
    stream: bar

This makes it easier to call the role once, but enable multiple streams efficiently.

Also, I think the defaults should have nothing. The calling playbook should provide vars.

I would rather use a list of dict here, such as:
tripleo_stream_enable_modules:
  - name: container-tools
    stream: 2.0
  - name: python36
    stream: 3.6
...

That way, you could make one call of the module, loop on all the modules you want to set, and then only run the distro-sync ONCE.
move to doc?
this can be dropped entirely.
if nothing has been added here, just drop the file/directory.
maybe add RedHat or something? not sure about the value/way - you probably want to compare with other roles.

Why do we want to ignore errors? We should handle errors properly, rather than use ignore_errors.

For example, use block/rescue to try something, then output a nice error message.
Can we get the list of all enabled once, then iterate through the resulting output, rather than calling dnf per module. This would be much faster.

This should not be necessary - awk will never return anything other than rc=0 IIRC. Alternatively, we should handle the error properly. failed_when: false is very bad practise.

One way of handling the error is to do something like "|| echo 'none'" so that you control the output, then use your controlled output later.
String matching is prone to problems when packages change their outputs.
spelling error
"available" maybe?

this will get available modules, not only the enabled.

Also, wondering if we shouldn't use "-C" - the dnf cache refresh might be long.
"action" or something - this role could be run outside of the update process (upgrade, deploy, and so on)

You probably want to add -C in order to avoid dnf cache refresh for this action.

Also, it might happen you get some garbage in the stderr, you probably want to add a "2>/dev/null" just before the pipe.
Here again -C in order to avoid dnf refresh :)
here again, -C
These should only be executed "when: tripleo_stream_enable | length > 0" otherwise we'd be doing expensive operations for nothing.

php                                        7.2 [d]                            common [d], devel, minimal                                     PHP scripting language
php                                        7.3                                common [d], devel, minimal                                     PHP scripting language

Might be interesting to actually leverage the shell and use some |awk '{print $1" "$2}' in order to get just the module name and the available stream(s). And since you check if "item.module" is in the list, we can even drop the stream version...

Also, seeing its usage in the reset_stream.yml, I'm wondering if it's really useful to list them all... Apparently, checking only the availability of the .module file would be enough?

Well, to be fair, this is a pretty useful debugging information if some issue occurs. You will at least have an initial picture on the state that will let you know what was enabled, available, etc... if the task is being run with no debugging the log won't be visible, so it won't add noise to the execution.

About checking the availability by verifying that the .module file exists...the purpose of this check is to verify that the user isn't trying to enable some stream for a module which doesn't exist and give some hint on what the issue is. We could also let the command fail when it will try to enable that stream (as the module won't be available), but I error log is a little ambiguous (it's not clear if the problem is in the module or the stream):

(undercloud) [stack@undercloud-0 ~]$ sudo dnf -y -C module enable tengu:2.0
Updating Subscription Management repositories.
/usr/lib/python3.6/site-packages/dateutil/parser/_parser.py:70: UnicodeWarning: decode() called on unicode string, see https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1693751
  instream = instream.decode()

Last metadata expiration check: 1:42:19 ago on Wed 12 Aug 2020 04:32:14 AM EDT.
Error: Problems in request:
missing groups or modules: tengu:2.0

dnf -C module list --available -q | awk '!x[$1]++ { print $1}'

that one provides a shorter list, using awk to remove the duplicated entries, and getting only the module names. That will probably allow to actually match the module in the reset_stream :)

config/general_config/minimal.yml.message:
stein is eol now, But this is mentioned in multiple places. 

Can be removed when we cleanup other places.

We should clean these everywhere, else difficult to follow when copying things around.

https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-quickstart/+/812638

deliverables/wallaby/ironic.yaml.message: reno suggests MAJOR version bump, though it's obviously not needed (by reading the 'upgrade' and 'other' notes), and that is not even possible due to 18.0.0 is already used in Xena. On the other hand, I think maybe the critical upgrade fix would worth a MINOR version bump, i.e. 17.1.0 as new version.
The severity of a bug fix does not affect semver. Quite the opposite: bumping a minor version may delay people from getting the fix in their systems.

deployment/nova/nova-api-container-puppe.message:
This going back and forth in another review [0] to see if we should add a single global parameter or not.

[0] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/+/781571

Based on the conversation in another change [0], I added a separate global option for this [1]. I also updated a separate change using the global that you can use for an example [2].

[0] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/+/781571/14
[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/+/806449/1
[2] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/+/804277
Same comment here as in the other patches that are using this variable. Should this variable be defined consistently? Just curious, which description wins, the last one registered?
if it's meant to be global, then the description should not say for Nova only. If we want service specific ones, I'd use NovaEnforceSecureRbac.

deployment/placement/placement-api-conta.message: or just set placement::policy::xxx: {get_param: PlacementEnforceSecureRbac} for both of them.

This trying to figure out if we're going to use a single global parameter for this or not [0].

[0] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/+/781571

Actually - looks like we're going with the global.

Based on the conversation in another change [0], I added a separate global option for this [1]. I also updated a separate change using the global that you can use for an example [2].

[0] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/+/781571/14
[1] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/+/806449/1
[2] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/+/804277
Sounds like we're going to pursue service-specific variables and then enable them via a single template, as opposed to a single global variable.
Same comment here as in the other patches. Should this global reference service specific information? Or should we be using the same global definition everywhere?

lib/keystone.message:
I'm afraid this is widely used [1] so unfortunately we can't drop this argument, it's part of the API.  

we could either ignore it, or migrate devsatck callers to a new function and just leave this as a wrapper (that might be my preferred solution, could even put a deprecation msg in)

[1] http://codesearch.openstack.org/?q=configure_auth_token_middleware&i=nope&files=&repos=
